job_title: Undefined in New York, NY
pros: The work hours are good.
cons: The management does not care about their employees.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Most colleagues are talented and supportive of your efforts. Immediate supervisors can be very supportive, though feedback is not formal. Some flexibility allowed in scheduling. Eager students. Multiple locations makes it possible to commute, though nearby campus is not guaranteed.
cons: No formal performance review. Incomplete faculty handbook, so basic contact and resource information must be gathered by word of mouth. Payroll decisions and schedule are not documented and must be requested. Some faculty have contracts, others don't. Salaries are not in writing. No increases over seven years. No seniority. No opportunity for raises or advancement. Administrative departments are territorial and decisions are made behind closed doors. Each campus is run separately, and differently, with different policies and expectations. Students are not advised, resulting in mis-registration, poor enrollment, classes canceled at the last minute.

job_title: Faculty Member in New York, NY
pros: There are none. I would give zero stars if I could.
cons:
Mismanagement, excessive and unrealistic workload is given for next to no pay and you are told all of your work is for "service to the college." They dump so much work on their faculty without any recognition or appreciation or pay. Students are ill-equipped to meet the challenges of higher education. HR is unprofessional, despicable, and dishonest. They lie at every turn and tell you a different story every time you ask. When you bring your concerns to HR or the deans, you are classified as the problem, not their systemic, dysfunctional, failing institution. Colleagues are backstabbing and argumentative and unprofessional. No sense of collegiality. One professor hit on a graduate student in front of me and the professor was never reprimanded! 
They treat their faculty like absolute dirt, and do nothing to support them or professionally develop them. They don't pay for professionally development, but want you to pay for continuing education on your own and then teach others. It's time for Touro to roll up the rug and close their doors for good. They are a blight on all higher education and their students are a disaster in the professional world.

review_title: Run less like a college and more like a kingdom...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Depending on where you work (which department) you may have some excellent coworkers.  Early Friday dismissal.  Off for Jewish holidays. Some departments (mine included) have a very laid back atmosphere.
cons: Extreme snobbishness from the higher ups.  Extreme. If you're a woman, it will be significantly more difficult in this setting; misogyny abounds.  Touro offers substandard salaries and a very backward administration. There are double standards for "favorites." There is no goodwill; in fact, there are people whose job it is to make sure that "reasonable accommodations" are near impossible to request. Only 21 hours of personal time, 42 hours of sick time, employees working there for less than five years accrue 70 hours of vacation time a year. We go by hours here because it's 7.5 hrs Mon-Thurs and 5 hours on Friday. The sick, personal, and vacation hours were determined by dividing 35 (hours per week) by 5 and getting 7.  So basically, it's to your benefit to get sick on Friday; avoid illness Mon-Thurs.

job_title: Enrollment in Los Alamitos, CA
pros: Free coffee and water. A few good people to work with. Off early every Friday and Jewish holidays. The university does offer a good quality education. I would still recommend any who wants to attend school online.
cons: Terrible management over Enrollment Counseling Department. Narcissistic, lying, conniving and fake individual. Beware if you're an strong educated female who has an opinion or idea because you will not be hired by this person. She is threaten by you, trust me. She is only interested in people she can manipulate or puppeteer like minions. If you report any wrongdoings or unethical practices to upper management, nothing will be done and you will be targeted.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Central Islip, NY
pros: Enjoyed interaction with students. Good (burt expensive, compared to salary) health benefits, Jewish holidays off, early Friday dismissal for Sabbath.. Easy to bond with lower support staff, because we're "all in the same boat."
cons: Low salaries, few raises, little room for advancement. As a former co-worker said, "They make you think you're lucky to have this job, and that there's nothing better out there." Two sets of layoffs in the past two years have left law school with what amounts to a skeleton crew. Main office in NYC very often seems like the right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing, and is QUITE clueless about the needs of the law school in particular. Mediocrity is not punished, nor is helpfulness/reliability/loyalty/effort rewarded, except for the "thanks of a grateful Touro." And that doesn't pay the bills.

review_title: This school does not reward effort and ability.
job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros:
A lot of time off, even when working. Most staff pretend to be busy when they only have an actual hour worth of work.
Changes are coming under the new college President.
cons:
Mediocrity RULES!!!
Rampant nepotism.
All systems are extremely outdated and manual. You will not gain any benefits you can use in a modern workforce.
Talented people are considered a threat and end soon up leaving after being harassed by administration and fellow staff. 
Effort is not recognized. appreciated or rewarded.

review_title: TouroCOM:  How to NOT manage effectively
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Jewish holidays off, near public transit, clean facilities, faculty/staff on fourth floor are hardworking,
cons: Most of the executive staff have inflated egos (big fish in a small pond complex) + nobody really knows how to manage (just because you're a physician, it doesn't mean you have any management/leadership skills in a business setting whatsoever), very low employee morale, incompetent clinical, student affairs, and admissions staff, and some executive staff are racist (at a school in Harlem.  Really?)

job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros:
Diversity and multicultural environment.  Adherence to legal, curriculum require-
ments as well as compliance/implementation of policies in the management of
the school.
cons:
Teaching assignments are sometimes given in different boroughs which may
require long travel times.  Textbooks for faculty members have gotten quite
difficult to get so that getting a copy may mean paying from one's own pocket.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
The only pros are department based, not college based:

Schedule and Days off

Culture of our department (not speaking of the entire college)

Fair and unbiased Chairperson/department leadership

Students in this department are academically striving to be better

Strong, long term full-time faculty, good adjunct support in our department
cons:
Human Resource department is joke - they are for the company, not the employee when you reach out to them.

Low pay and no room for professional growth

It's an old man's club - if you are a woman, especially a non-Jewish one, good luck going anywhere. The executives are pre-dominantly old Jewish men who live in the past and treat it more like a business rather than an educational institution.

The culture of the college is joke. It has a bad reputation on the streets, and most students come in thinking the worst, but they get financial aid, so they stay.

You get the same story year after year why there is no cost-of-living raises, or merit raises, and it's a pack of lies.

Low academic standings in the liberal art programs, and then they expect programs to take students into pre-professional programs because they are Touro students. Then they fail out when the work is actually challenging.

The college is more worried about meeting the "numbers" with students, rather than admitting quality over quantity.

Students have said certain liberal art programs are a joke, waste of time, and their grades are handed to them, not representing true academic success. Sets up the student for failure in professional programs and the real world.

NEPOTISM at it's finest!!

review_title: RUN!!!!! DO NOT WORK HERE! SERIOUSLY!!! Consider this your warning.
job_title: Administrative Employee in New York, NY
pros: Some staff members are really great. It may take a few months to find out who the good and genuine people are, but when you do it will make your days easier. You get off for all of the high Jewish holidays. All Manhattan offices are located close to Penn Station. Once you learn what you actually have to do to keep your job, you'll learn that you don't have to do much work during the day. There is a Hannukah party. If you get a good boss you won't experience most of the horrible things about working here. You can form a network with the other people who are suffering from the horrible experience of working here.
cons: You will not get off on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day (a federal holiday), New Year's Eve, or Good Friday. Touro is run like a small business instead of an international university.  They are slow to do anything and everything. The pay is low. If you are lucky you will get a "cost of living" raise, depending on the year. It will probably be a percentage in the single digits. A lot of people gossip and pretend to know your personal business.  You will not receive onboarding when you start. Be prepared to figure out your job by yourself. If you are a good employee you will probably be asked to do everyone else's job. All of the horrible co-workers are seriously horrible. Some people that work at Touro act like spoiled and entitled children. Some employees act like their position at Touro is the only job they ever had. Your boss probably won't encourage professional development. If you get professional development approved, good luck getting reimbursed or getting your costs covered by the school. Touro will go through hoops just to say no to approving your travel expenses.  HR doesn't do anything to address any personnel issues in the workplace. Every time something goes wrong or if there is a delay, someone will say "That's Touro for you" or "That's how it goes around here" instead of providing a solution. There is no room for growth. You may actually get laughed at if you ask for a raise. You probably will have a very old computer to use. You will probably have to share a small office with a few people. Your office may be located in a basement and you probably won't have a window.

job_title: Administrative Associate in Bay Shore, NY
pros: The time off for all the Jewish Holidays
cons: They are a backward college and support staff departments are run as if it's still 1987...Touro does not invest in technology. Most of the support staff that work with the students have never been to college themselves. The Bay Shore Campus pays it's people peanuts and thinks that the time off they give you should compensate for low pay and poor working conditions. Touro has no admission standards and will accept anyone who can pay the $500 deposit.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: People friendly. great place to further your education, good staff and good location in the New your city area if you live in the area.
cons: They don't Pay enough money and there is no room for advancement in my job field, The company don't like to spend money for what the need.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Lots of Jewish holidays and administration has deans with bachelor degrees. Big family business with lots of Jewish nepotism. This institution is run like a sweat shop based on republican ideology
cons:
Lowest pay in NYC PhD only $2000/ course not seen a pay raise since the beginning of Touro college. Anti Union no benefits or retirement plan for adjunct faculty.
More than 50% are adjuncts. Teacher teach anything and to please the students to be rehired. Poor quality of instructions. Administration mostly Jewish are the best paid in the industry. In fact the founder was the highest paid university president in the US.
No promotion or future as a professor at Touro college this opinion is based on facts not speculation or conjecture.

review_title: Beware of Position in Human Resources
job_title: HRIS Manager in New York, NY
pros: Ostensibly, a friendly work environment (I was there for only a week). HR professionals I've worked with, below director level, are very friendly and professional.
cons: They gave me exactly one week, before deciding my skills were not on par with what was required. Regardless of who I am as a person or a professional, it is only a fair assessment either BEFORE extending an offer, or well over a week after (usually 3 months or so). The impact this has had on me is profound - and I feel it would be remiss if I didn't warn other people.

review_title: A joke of an educational institution
job_title: Librarian in New York, NY
pros:
Midtown campus is located in a great neighborhood
There are a handful of excellent people
cons:
Very low academic standards & poor student support
Sluggish and out of touch administration
Very few perks of any kind
Culture of complaint and dissatisfaction without any real effort to improve
Everything is more difficult than it needs to be

review_title: Great people, lots of beuracracy, low pay
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great location. Colleagues are good people. Fun to work. Good benefits. Early Friday release. Paid Jewish holidays.
cons: No room for evolvement within company. Low pay. No raises for the past 3 years. Seniors will keep adding work that is not part of your job description without compensating you for it.

review_title: Work of two people get paid half the salary- TouroCOM Harlem
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: coworkers at the Harlem campus site are nice and get along with well. Staff and faculty easy to get along with.
cons: low salary , unwilling to give employees raises, atmosphere of the work place was negative, benefits are not great, one person is given the role of two people, the administrative staff is overworked and underpaid. Management doesn't show appreciation for employees.

review_title: Lack of willingness to change the status-quo
job_title: Administrative Associate in New York, NY
pros: Campuses are closed for the numerous Jewish holidays, enjoyed working with youth and participating in college programming. Tuition breaks for self and children.
cons: RED TAPE for ANY change, no autonomy or trust of employees to make decisions. Lack of growth in position and salary. Ideas to help make the school better are discouraged. Stuck in the past.

review_title: A third tier college that does care about their students
job_title: Adjunct Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: You can teach without a doctorate degree. The deans are very passionate about education
cons: The facilities are a joke. They are old, dirty and have no modern equipment. The pay is not why you teach here. The support staff is unhelpful and students seem to be there because they have financial aid.

job_title: Library Assistant in Passaic, NJ
pros: Jewish Holidays are given as off days.  Great for seeing a variety of people.  Easy to get along with your co-workers
cons: Might be limiting depending on skill set.  Might not be able to obtain desired location.  Salary not only dependent on skill but also depends on Departmental Budget.

job_title: Librarian in New York, NY
pros: The location was really great. The students very sweet and friendly. Lots Jewish holidays off especially in the beginning of September.
cons: I was constantly harassed by my immediate supervisor.  He would follow me around and berate me for no reason. He wouldn't talk to me so I never knew what his expectations were.  He wanted to know every time I went to the bathroom. I filed a complaint with HR against him and tried talking about his behavior with his supervisor. Instead of addressing this issue, they gave me a final warning and decided to give me a review on the spot.

job_title: Tutor in New York, NY
pros: Flexible hours to work, good staff to deal with, the money is reasonable relatively to this industry.and very easy students
cons: There is not to grow from this type of job. It is convenient to work there as a temp but there is no future. As well as you don't get any benefits.

review_title: Not bad as a side job.
job_title: Faculty Instructor in New York, NY
pros:
(Applies to W23rd St. Campus.)
Some very motivated students.
Excellent support from some department chairs.
Evening hours.
Some excellent faculty.
Excellent library, librarians.
Good access to technical and media equipment.
cons:
Very low pay.
Some very unmotivated students.
Poor academic reputation.
Some irresponsible faculty.

Students expect grade inflation.
No room to advance.

Terrible advisement department.

job_title: Front End Developer in New York, NY
pros: Each department at Touro is its own ecosystem. Working with web communications was a wonderful experience. It's supportive and collaborative environment, flexible schedule and freedom to get your job done vs micromanagement.
cons: Opportunities for growth are limited in technology field simply due to the nature of pace at higher education institutions (it's slower than other places). There's not much technical guidance, which also leads to lack of growth and challenge.

job_title: Faculty Instructor in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Somewhat flexible schedule , accessible administration, decent benefits.
cons:
Small Health Science Department in Brooklyn has lost 20 employees [4 administrative, 5 clinical supervisors, 6 adjuncts and 5 full time faculty]  in 8 years  due to being overworked, underpaid ,and 
disrespected.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: wonderful students great staff very nice environment good treatment friendly people elevator is a plus i like my experience think its cool.
cons: i like the place not many cons just a few teacher need to be on time and know their schedule

review_title: Outrageously unfair treatment with little recourse for redress.

cons: Very unequal distribution of courseloads , adminstrative duties, and salaries . Several accomplished professionals kicked to the curb for questioning these random practices. At will empoyment , so no job security.

review_title: Graduate Speech Department A Mixed Bag

cons: All founding members of the department have left for greener pastures , there was no attempt to incorporate their suggestions for improvement .

job_title: Senior Project Manager in New York, NY

Good work-life balance.
Some very smart people work there or used to work there.

1/ Very hierarchical. 

2/ Once a strategy is set, it is hard for them to pivot. "That ship has sailed," is a phrase I hear often.

3/ I have seen bullying at various occasions.

review_title: DO NOT WORK HERE for LONG
job_title: in New York, NY

They are just winging it. they have no idea what they are doing. the lower admin staff are the oly people who help the students but they dont have any resources and they get minimal pay. Racail discrimination. Jews and the white boys and girsl are the only once getting any where here.

job_title: Coordinator in New York, NY

cons: I was very happy working here, so not many cons. I would suggest having a set growth plan because it can take a while to grow into a new title.

job_title: in Brooklyn, NY

job_title: Director in New York, NY

Christmas Day is not acknowledged as a holiday, but the 4th of July and Memorial Day and MLK Day are

10-15 minute wait on elevators at Administrative Office or 8 flight walk up

review_title: Enjoyed the opportunity to bring the real world to academia.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brightwaters, NY
pros: The schedule was in the evening allowing me to work my "day job". We got paid for very Jewish Holiday. there was a great deal of independence.
cons: The larest concern appeared to be the retention of students and there were seceral underqualified students.

review_title: Touro College Former Student Services Staff Review

cons: low paying salaries and expensive benefits. Office space is limited and many student service offices are shared working areas.

pros:
The good point is that it helps you create good teaching experience and network with others for other positions.
Resources are available for enhancing faculty's publication material.
cons: Adjunct do the teaching while the full time faculty is focused on getting published.

review_title: I was motivated and enjoyed helping Touro become a better college with a better HR Department.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Good Benefits
Experienced and Friendly co-workers
Good vacations
New Projects
cons: In transition but getting better

cons: 1) Pockets of dated supervision systems still exist 2) Infrastructure cannot always support new projects which causes an added layer of confusion and work.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: It is a very laid back environment, they do not expect from you to work much, Fridays are half-day long. Off for many Jewish holidays in the Fall.
cons: Low salary, no opportunities for career advancement for administrative staff.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in New York, NY
pros:
Lots of evening hours.
Dep't Chair is Accommodating and Fair
cons:
Salary is exceptionally low

job_title: Early Childhood Educator in New York, NY
pros: Great staff & students   Diversified curriculum.
cons: Pay scale.  Upgrade benefits package. Provide incentives & recognition for staff with longevity. Additional staff trainings & development to calendar year.

job_title: BURSAR in New York, NY
pros: Holidays. Short days on Fridays.
cons:
Very low pay. Virtually no raise in years. No bonuses. Inhumanly enormous work load that needs to be done by deadline while always understaffed.
No praise or appreciation from bosses. Too many bosses and not enough workers.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Brooklyn, NY
